abstract.p: Neal L Wolkoff letter responds to June 10 news article on high gasoline prices in Midwest; suggests problem may have resulted from miscues by EPA, which indicated it was considering waiving requirement for cleaner-burning gasoline in affected cities

block.p: Gasoline prices have soared in the Midwest, and the government does not know why (''In Gas Prices, Misery and Mystery,'' news article, June 14). One plausible explanation is that weeks before the start of the reformulated gasoline program in Chicago and Milwaukee, the Environmental Protection Agency signaled that it was considering waiving the requirement for cleaner-burning gas, called RFG-2, in those cities for the summer.

Gasoline prices have soared in the Midwest, and the government does not know why (''In Gas Prices, Misery and Mystery,'' news article, June 14). One plausible explanation is that weeks before the start of the reformulated gasoline program in Chicago and Milwaukee, the Environmental Protection Agency signaled that it was considering waiving the requirement for cleaner-burning gas, called RFG-2, in those cities for the summer.

It is logical that refiners would curtail production and storage of the cleaner gas because of the chance that a less expensive alternative -- conventional gasoline -- would be allowed. This would lower the value of RFG without regard to the extra cost incurred in producing it. Bad policy, not collusion, may be at the root of this price shock.
NEAL L. WOLKOFF New York, June 14, 2000
The writer is executive vice president of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
